body:
I agree that there is a common wrapper logic being used for all CRDs in Helm 2 recently. Taking a closer look at how CRDs are installed and managed would and how we can improve that process would be appreciated.

I would love to see a practical example! It seems like it's an idea worth investigating. I'm having a hard time conceptualizing this, so having a practical example to play with and understand the solution might be a good way forward to see if this is feasible or not (as well as provide feedback on the design).

As I see it, we have four major problems to sort out with CRDs:

- Install order: CRDs have to be installed in a separate operation from any _usage of_ (instances of) that CRD. 
- Compatibility detection: If a CRD exists, and a request to install the CRD comes in, but the api versions are different, what do we do?
- Update process: CRDs are possibly global, while most other kinds that appear in Helm charts are not. So under what conditions can a chart that contains a CRD upgrade the CRD?
- Deletion of a CRD: When a CRD is deleted, all of its instances are deleted. And CRDs are global. Under what conditions can Helm delete a CRD (clearly, it's not by default)

As far as I can tell, the above makes it easier to solve the first point. But is it in any way helping or hindering with the others? I don't want to take a shot at solving just one prong, only to discover that that solution prevented us from solving the others.

The proposal does not explain what the mechanics of the `crd/` directory are. Are CRD YAML files treated as templates, too? Do they get the same context as other templates? Are they always evaluated BEFORE the others? And if so, can anything be injected from the CRD template eval into the context used for regular eval? What happens if a non-CRD is placed in the `crd` directory? For example, if I have a deployment that is a CRD controller, it is often necessary for that controller to be up and running before instances can be reliably processed. So do I put the controller objects in the CRD folder?

Just [spitballing](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/spitball)...

> Install order: CRDs have to be installed in a separate operation from any usage of (instances of) that CRD.

The CRD directory would make it easy to figure out where they were to install them first. We would not need to parse all the templates first. This could extend to the whole dependency tree.

> Compatibility detection: If a CRD exists, and a request to install the CRD comes in, but the api versions are different, what do we do?

This is the hard one. [There is a whole page in the docs on versioning CRDs](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/access-kubernetes-api/custom-resources/custom-resource-definition-versioning/). While I'm open to suggestions, I would argue we notify the user and let them decide what to do.

> Update process: CRDs are possibly global, while most other kinds that appear in Helm charts are not. So under what conditions can a chart that contains a CRD upgrade the CRD?

When there is a change such as a new apiVersion, change in storage/serving, etc. I would propose this is an operation that notifies the user of the coming change and asks them to accept it. A human in the loop because this could be a destructive change.

> Deletion of a CRD: When a CRD is deleted, all of its instances are deleted. And CRDs are global. Under what conditions can Helm delete a CRD (clearly, it's not by default)

Always manual? Directions about deleting them with big flashers like we used to have on geocities for the under construction pages.

@technosophos you raised a lot of good questions. Ones worth airing and discussing publicly.

> The CRD directory would make it easy to figure out where they were to install them first. We would not need to parse all the templates first. This could extend to the whole dependency tree.

Placing CRDs in a specific directory in the chart package gives us a more reliable way to handle them separately. For example, we could render all the CRDs in the chart and sub-charts first and then install them before installing the rest (just an example, the idea is we can use it to make the right decisions). I guess there's no reason we can't do this with the current `crd-install` hook, but I'm not sure what the future of hooks are in Helm 3 and I also feel like annotations aren't the best way of defining these if we have the opportunity to extend the chart format.

Completely agree with @mattfarina's comment, Helm should not try to do anything clever in most of these scenarios, I think the goal here would be to just provide more info to the operator so that they can decide how to proceed.

`Have a crd directory alongside the templates directory`   - is this necessary?  We know that a CRD has the following top level items in their declaration:

```
apiVersion: apiextensions.k8s.io/v1beta1
kind: CustomResourceDefinition
```

would it be within Helm's scope to look at the apiVersion/kind of resources and act on them based on the resource type?  If we know its a CRD by the apiVersion/kind then we can treat it as a CRD, however we decide to treat them.
